elements.content: In this paper, two 3D anionic metal–organic frameworks, [(CH3CH2)2NH2]·[Zn­(BTC)1/3(PyC)]·1/2CH3CN·2H2O (NKU-102) and [(CH3CH2)2NH2]·[Zn2(BTC) (PyC)]·1.5H2O·DEF (NKU-103), were constructed from the same reaction system at different temperature. Though both are of anionic framework, NKU-102 possesses a sealed 3D framework based on octahedral cage and shows negligible adsorption capacity of organic dyes, whereas NKU-103 features an open triangular microchannel surrounded by two types of helical chains, and thus exhibits outstanding size-selective adsorption toward small cationic organic dyes.
elements.clean_text: In this paper, two 3D anionic metal-organic frameworks, [(CH3CH2)2NH2]⋅[Zn(BTC)1/3(PyC)]⋅1/2CH3CN⋅2H2O (NKU-102) and [(CH3CH2)2NH2]⋅[Zn2(BTC) (PyC)]⋅1.5H2O⋅DEF (NKU-103), were constructed from the same reaction system at different temperature. Though both are of anionic framework, NKU-102 possesses a sealed 3D framework based on octahedral cage and shows negligible adsorption capacity of organic dyes, whereas NKU-103 features an open triangular microchannel surrounded by two types of helical chains, and thus exhibits outstanding size-selective adsorption toward small cationic organic dyes.

elements.content: Two anionic MOFs have been synthesized with the same reaction system at different temperature. NKU-102 shows a cage-based sealed architecture, while NKU-103 features a homochiral framework involving triangular nanochannels and exhibits excellent performance in adsorbing and separating small cationic dyes drove both by electrostatic interaction and size-exclusion effect.
elements.clean_text: Two anionic MOFs have been synthesized with the same reaction system at different temperature. NKU-102 shows a cage-based sealed architecture, while NKU-103 features a homochiral framework involving triangular nanochannels and exhibits excellent performance in adsorbing and separating small cationic dyes drove both by electrostatic interaction and size-exclusion effect.

elements.content: As a class of crystalline structures built from the ordered assembly of organic ligands and metal ions or clusters, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) display versatile structure-related properties and hence have potential applications in various fields, including gas storage, catalysis, separation, luminescence, sensors, and so forth. The “one pot” solvothermal method has been the prevalent paradigm for MOFs synthesis since it came into being. However, it is often hard for this method to predict the crystal structure of the resultant product. This situation has been improved to a certain extent by rational choices of organic ligands and metal ions. In contrast to limited species of metal ions, diverse organic ligands have been developed based on versatile backbone and coordination groups including carboxylates, heterocycle, phosphonate, and sulfonate, which substantially expands the scope of synthesis options to obtain desirable MOFs. Among prevalent coordination groups, carboxylate and N-heterocycle are of perennial favor because of their good affinity toward transition metal ions. It is worth noting that one of N-heterocycle groups, the parazole group, possesses similar coordination modes to that of carboxylic group but subtly different coordination ability. So, combining parazole and carboxylate group in a linker would produce novel ligands with intriguing coordination properties. For example, 4-pyrazolecarboxylic acid (H2PyC) displays similar linear coordination orientation with well-investigated 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2BDC) (), but with different responsive behaviors to varied reaction conditions.
elements.clean_text: As a class of crystalline structures built from the ordered assembly of organic ligands and metal ions or clusters, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) display versatile structure-related properties and hence have potential applications in various fields, including gas storage, catalysis, separation, luminescence, sensors, and so forth. The "one pot" solvothermal method has been the prevalent paradigm for MOFs synthesis since it came into being. However, it is often hard for this method to predict the crystal structure of the resultant product. This situation has been improved to a certain extent by rational choices of organic ligands and metal ions. In contrast to limited species of metal ions, diverse organic ligands have been developed based on versatile backbone and coordination groups including carboxylates, heterocycle, phosphonate, and sulfonate, which substantially expands the scope of synthesis options to obtain desirable MOFs. Among prevalent coordination groups, carboxylate and N-heterocycle are of perennial favor because of their good affinity toward transition metal ions. It is worth noting that one of N-heterocycle groups, the parazole group, possesses similar coordination modes to that of carboxylic group but subtly different coordination ability. So, combining parazole and carboxylate group in a linker would produce novel ligands with intriguing coordination properties. For example, 4-pyrazolecarboxylic acid (H2PyC) displays similar linear coordination orientation with well-investigated 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2BDC) (), but with different responsive behaviors to varied reaction conditions.

elements.content: Classical coordination modes of carboxylate (a) and parazole (c). Electrostatic potential map of H2BDC (b) and H2PyC (d). The structures were optimized at the level of B3LYP/6-311g (d) by Gaussian 09 package (Supporting Information).
elements.clean_text: 1  Classical coordination modes of carboxylate (a) and parazole (c). Electrostatic potential map of H2BDC (b) and H2PyC (d). The structures were optimized at the level of B3LYP/6-311g (d) by Gaussian 09 package (Supporting Information).

elements.content: In addition, using more than one ligand is an effective strategy to build novel MOF architecture. Particularly, two or more carboxylate linkers of different topologies are often employed in combination to construct MOFs with particular structures and properties. For example, in the case of UMCM-2 MOF-205 and MOF-210, linear and trigonal carboxylate linkers assembly together and generate a framework of exceptional porosities and gas uptake capacities. H2PyC exhibits similar coordination behaviors to linear carboxylate ligands; however, it is less explored in its collaborative coordination with carboxylate ligands. Based on the above consideration and as a continuation of our previous work on mixed-ligand synthesis, the collaborative coordination of linear H2PyC (H2PyC = 4-pyrazolecarboxylic acid) and trigonal H3BTC (H3BTC = 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid) toward zinc ions has been investigated (Scheme S1). As a result, here we present two new three-dimensional (3D) anionic Zn-MOFs, [(CH3CH2)2NH2]·[Zn (BTC)1/3(PyC)]·1/2CH3CN·2H2O (NKU-102), and [(CH3CH2)2NH2]·[Zn2(BTC) (PyC)]·1.5H2O ·DEF (NKU-103) (NKU = Nankai University) synthesized through solvothermal methods at different temperature. NKU-102 has a sealed achiral architecture based on octahedral cages, whereas NKU-103 features an open triangular microchannel surrounded by two types of helical chains, and thus exhibits size-selective adsorption of small cationic dyes.
elements.clean_text: In addition, using more than one ligand is an effective strategy to build novel MOF architecture. Particularly, two or more carboxylate linkers of different topologies are often employed in combination to construct MOFs with particular structures and properties. For example, in the case of UMCM-2 MOF-205 and MOF-210, linear and trigonal carboxylate linkers assembly together and generate a framework of exceptional porosities and gas uptake capacities. H2PyC exhibits similar coordination behaviors to linear carboxylate ligands; however, it is less explored in its collaborative coordination with carboxylate ligands. Based on the above consideration and as a continuation of our previous work on mixed-ligand synthesis, the collaborative coordination of linear H2PyC (H2PyC = 4-pyrazolecarboxylic acid) and trigonal H3BTC (H3BTC = 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid) toward zinc ions has been investigated (Scheme S1). As a result, here we present two new three-dimensional (3D) anionic Zn-MOFs, [(CH3CH2)2NH2]⋅[Zn (BTC)1/3(PyC)]⋅1/2CH3CN⋅2H2O (NKU-102), and [(CH3CH2)2NH2]⋅[Zn2(BTC) (PyC)]⋅1.5H2O ⋅DEF (NKU-103) (NKU = Nankai University) synthesized through solvothermal methods at different temperature. NKU-102 has a sealed achiral architecture based on octahedral cages, whereas NKU-103 features an open triangular microchannel surrounded by two types of helical chains, and thus exhibits size-selective adsorption of small cationic dyes.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction study reveals that NKU-102 crystallizes in the trigonal crystal system and the R3̅ space group. The asymmetric unit consists of one Zn­(II) ion, one PyC2– ligand, and a third of BTC3– ligand. In this unit, the Zn­(II) ion centers inside a distorted tetrahedron geometry, surrounded by two oxygen atoms and two nitrogen atoms (a). Neighboring two Zn­(II) ions are double-connected by two pyrazole groups to give a dinuclear Zn­(II) cluster with a Zn···Zn distance of 3.6984 Å. The dinuclear clusters are further linked by the carboxylate group of PyC2– to produce a 3D anionic framework. There is one kind of 1D hexagonal channel inside the framework extending along c-axis (b), which is blocked by the coordinating BTC3– ligands staggered stacking in parallel with a face-to-face distance of 11.0192 Å. Close examination further reveals that NKU-102 also can be regarded as a framework based on one kind of octahedral cage (d), formed by six dinuclear Zn­(II) vertexes linked with six PyC2– and two BTC3– and may enclose a sphere of 10.6 Å diameter (c). Each cage is surrounded with six neighboring cages by sharing each vertex between two cages, leading to a 3D sealed architecture (e) that occupied by the counterions [(CH3CH2)2NH2]+ derived from the decomposition of solvent DEF (N,N-diethylformamide). The effective closed volume is predicted to be 60.6% (4677.7 Å3 of the 7718.0 Å3 unit cell volume) based on PLATON analysis after removing all of the guest molecules (Supporting Information). Topologically, simplifying binuclear centers as 6-connected node and BTC3– as 3-connected node gives a 3D binodal (3, 6)-connected “loh1” topology with the Schläfli symbol of (43)2(46.66.83)3. (Figure S1).
elements.clean_text: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction study reveals that NKU-102 crystallizes in the trigonal crystal system and the R3̅ space group. The asymmetric unit consists of one Zn(II) ion, one PyC2- ligand, and a third of BTC3- ligand. In this unit, the Zn(II) ion centers inside a distorted tetrahedron geometry, surrounded by two oxygen atoms and two nitrogen atoms (a). Neighboring two Zn(II) ions are double-connected by two pyrazole groups to give a dinuclear Zn(II) cluster with a Zn⋅⋅⋅Zn distance of 3.6984 Å. The dinuclear clusters are further linked by the carboxylate group of PyC2- to produce a 3D anionic framework. There is one kind of 1D hexagonal channel inside the framework extending along c-axis (b), which is blocked by the coordinating BTC3- ligands staggered stacking in parallel with a face-to-face distance of 11.0192 Å. Close examination further reveals that NKU-102 also can be regarded as a framework based on one kind of octahedral cage (d), formed by six dinuclear Zn(II) vertexes linked with six PyC2- and two BTC3- and may enclose a sphere of 10.6 Å diameter (c). Each cage is surrounded with six neighboring cages by sharing each vertex between two cages, leading to a 3D sealed architecture (e) that occupied by the counterions [(CH3CH2)2NH2]+ derived from the decomposition of solvent DEF (N,N-diethylformamide). The effective closed volume is predicted to be 60.6% (4677.7 Å3 of the 7718.0 Å3 unit cell volume) based on PLATON analysis after removing all of the guest molecules (Supporting Information). Topologically, simplifying binuclear centers as 6-connected node and BTC3- as 3-connected node gives a 3D binodal (3, 6)-connected "loh1" topology with the Schläfli symbol of (43)2(46.66.83)3. (Figure S1).

elements.content: Crystal structure of NKU-102. (a) Coordination environment of Zinc ion; (b) 1D hexagonal channels constructed by PyC2– and zinc ions; (c) octahedral cage Zn12(BTC)2(PyC)6; (d) simplified octahedral cage; (e) packing of octahedral cages.
elements.clean_text: 2  Crystal structure of NKU-102. (a) Coordination environment of Zinc ion; (b) 1D hexagonal channels constructed by PyC2- and zinc ions; (c) octahedral cage Zn12(BTC)2(PyC)6; (d) simplified octahedral cage; (e) packing of octahedral cages.

elements.content: NKU-103 crystallizes in the chiral space group P3221 and the asymmetric unit contains two kinds of Zn­(II) ions, one PyC2– ligand and one BTC3– ligand. The framework is anionic and balanced by the [(CH3CH2)2NH2]+ ions originating from the decomposition of DEF. Both Zn1 and Zn2 are four-coordinated by three O atoms from three carboxylate groups and one nitrogen atom from one PyC2– ligand, resembling a distorted tetrahedral geometry (a). Zn1 and Zn2 are triple bridged together by one pyrazolyl group and two carboxylate groups to generate a dinuclear cluster with a Zn···Zn distance of 3.3338(15) Å. Neighboring dinuclear centers are further connected by the BTC3– ligands in μ4:η2η1η1 mode to generate a 3D framework (b). Detailed analysis reveals that the framework contains a type of left-handed single helix (d) and a type of right-handed double-helix (c). The former one generated through the coordination between Zn ions and BTC3– surrounds a small triangular channel blocked by coordination PyC2– ligands. For the latter one, the two helixes formed through the coordination between Zn ions and BTC3– are linked with each other by PyC2– ligands, to yield an open triangular helical channels with a cross section of approximately 9 Å (considering the van der Waals radius of atoms) (g). The effective free volume is predicted to be 68.1% (Supporting Information). It is worth noting that all the helical channels are right-handed and the 3D framework is of intrinsic homochirality (Flack = 0). This framework could be rationalized as a (3,5)-connected network with the Schläfli symbol of­(4.52) (4.53.62.73.8) (Figure S2).
elements.clean_text: NKU-103 crystallizes in the chiral space group P3221 and the asymmetric unit contains two kinds of Zn(II) ions, one PyC2- ligand and one BTC3- ligand. The framework is anionic and balanced by the [(CH3CH2)2NH2]+ ions originating from the decomposition of DEF. Both Zn1 and Zn2 are four-coordinated by three O atoms from three carboxylate groups and one nitrogen atom from one PyC2- ligand, resembling a distorted tetrahedral geometry (a). Zn1 and Zn2 are triple bridged together by one pyrazolyl group and two carboxylate groups to generate a dinuclear cluster with a Zn⋅⋅⋅Zn distance of 3.3338(15) Å. Neighboring dinuclear centers are further connected by the BTC3- ligands in μ4:η2η1η1 mode to generate a 3D framework (b). Detailed analysis reveals that the framework contains a type of left-handed single helix (d) and a type of right-handed double-helix (c). The former one generated through the coordination between Zn ions and BTC3- surrounds a small triangular channel blocked by coordination PyC2- ligands. For the latter one, the two helixes formed through the coordination between Zn ions and BTC3- are linked with each other by PyC2- ligands, to yield an open triangular helical channels with a cross section of approximately 9 Å (considering the van der Waals radius of atoms) (g). The effective free volume is predicted to be 68.1% (Supporting Information). It is worth noting that all the helical channels are right-handed and the 3D framework is of intrinsic homochirality (Flack = 0). This framework could be rationalized as a (3,5)-connected network with the Schläfli symbol of(4.52) (4.53.62.73.8) (Figure S2).

elements.content: Crystal structure of NKU-103. (a) Coordination environment of zinc ion; (b) framework built from BTC3– ligands and Zn (II); (c) right-handed double-helix; (d) left-handed single helix; (e) 3D framework with open triangular helical channel; (f) tiling representation of the open 1D chiral helical channels; (g) 1D chiral helical channels.
elements.clean_text: 3  Crystal structure of NKU-103. (a) Coordination environment of zinc ion; (b) framework built from BTC3- ligands and Zn (II); (c) right-handed double-helix; (d) left-handed single helix; (e) 3D framework with open triangular helical channel; (f) tiling representation of the open 1D chiral helical channels; (g) 1D chiral helical channels.

elements.content: The syntheses of NKU-102 and NKU-103 are carried out with the same reaction system but at different temperature, which brings about different coordination modes of ligands between NKU-102 and NKU-103 as shown in Figure S3. BTC3– adopts μ4:η2η1η1 mode in NKU-102 and μ3:η1η1η1 mode in NKU-103, while PyC2– adopts μ4:η2η2 mode in NKU-102 and μ3:η2η1 mode in NKU-103. It is of interest that parazole group of H2PyC adopts identical coordination fashion in NKU-102 and NKU-103, whereas the carboxylate group of H2PyC as well as one carboxylate group of H3BTC display distinct coordination fashions, that is the monodentate mode in NKU-102 and the bidentate mode in NKU-103. This indicates that parazole group, though has similar coordination modes to carboxylate group, exhibits slightly different response to temperature from the latter. As result, different coordination modes of ligands results in different architecture for the two compounds. NKU-102 is of 3D sealed structure constructed based on an cage, with a space volume of 60.6% blockd by the coordinated BTC3– ligands, while NKU-103 features a homochiral framework with two types of helical chains and open triangular nanochannels. The effective free volume of NKU-103 is 68.1% and the triangular nanochannels are accessible to eligible guest molecules, which enables it to be a potential adsorbent for certain chemicals.
elements.clean_text: The syntheses of NKU-102 and NKU-103 are carried out with the same reaction system but at different temperature, which brings about different coordination modes of ligands between NKU-102 and NKU-103 as shown in Figure S3. BTC3- adopts μ4:η2η1η1 mode in NKU-102 and μ3:η1η1η1 mode in NKU-103, while PyC2- adopts μ4:η2η2 mode in NKU-102 and μ3:η2η1 mode in NKU-103. It is of interest that parazole group of H2PyC adopts identical coordination fashion in NKU-102 and NKU-103, whereas the carboxylate group of H2PyC as well as one carboxylate group of H3BTC display distinct coordination fashions, that is the monodentate mode in NKU-102 and the bidentate mode in NKU-103. This indicates that parazole group, though has similar coordination modes to carboxylate group, exhibits slightly different response to temperature from the latter. As result, different coordination modes of ligands results in different architecture for the two compounds. NKU-102 is of 3D sealed structure constructed based on an cage, with a space volume of 60.6% blockd by the coordinated BTC3- ligands, while NKU-103 features a homochiral framework with two types of helical chains and open triangular nanochannels. The effective free volume of NKU-103 is 68.1% and the triangular nanochannels are accessible to eligible guest molecules, which enables it to be a potential adsorbent for certain chemicals.

elements.content: Before the adsorption investigation, the purity and stability of NKU-102 and NKU-103 were evaluated. The highly crystalline purity of these two compounds was manifested by the good matching between the experimental PXRD patterns and the simulated data (Figures S4 and S5). Meanwhile, good thermal stability was also proved by thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) as showed in Figures S6 and S7. The initial slow decline of TGA profile observed for NKU-102 and NKU-103 indicates gradual escape of the lattice molecules from the framework, and the decomposition of the framework does not start until increasing temperature to 255 °C for NKU-102 and 250 °C for NKU-103, which testifies to their good thermal stability.
elements.clean_text: Before the adsorption investigation, the purity and stability of NKU-102 and NKU-103 were evaluated. The highly crystalline purity of these two compounds was manifested by the good matching between the experimental PXRD patterns and the simulated data (Figures S4 and S5). Meanwhile, good thermal stability was also proved by thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) as showed in Figures S6 and S7. The initial slow decline of TGA profile observed for NKU-102 and NKU-103 indicates gradual escape of the lattice molecules from the framework, and the decomposition of the framework does not start until increasing temperature to 255 °C for NKU-102 and 250 °C for NKU-103, which testifies to their good thermal stability.

elements.content: As one of the most common pollutants in factory sewage, organic dyes were chosen herein as the adsorbates. Organic dyes are widely employed in textile, plastics, paint, leather, and paper industries, which on the other hand leads to serious environmental pollution due to their high toxicity to aquatic creatures and carcinogenic effects to human health. So, effective removal of dye pollutants is a crucial step during the treatment of factory sewage. MOFs are promising candidates for selectively adsorbing pollutants due to their characteristics, such as modifiable porosities, high surface areas, and opened active sites. Above crystal structure analysis also reveals some vital advantages of NKU-103 acting as adsorbent: (a) The essential high porosity for adsorbent. (b) The anionic framework has preferential adsorption for positive dyes through electrostatic interaction ionic selectivity. (c) The moderate pore sizes endow the frameworks with size-exclusion effect.
elements.clean_text: As one of the most common pollutants in factory sewage, organic dyes were chosen herein as the adsorbates. Organic dyes are widely employed in textile, plastics, paint, leather, and paper industries, which on the other hand leads to serious environmental pollution due to their high toxicity to aquatic creatures and carcinogenic effects to human health. So, effective removal of dye pollutants is a crucial step during the treatment of factory sewage. MOFs are promising candidates for selectively adsorbing pollutants due to their characteristics, such as modifiable porosities, high surface areas, and opened active sites. Above crystal structure analysis also reveals some vital advantages of NKU-103 acting as adsorbent: (a) The essential high porosity for adsorbent. (b) The anionic framework has preferential adsorption for positive dyes through electrostatic interaction ionic selectivity. (c) The moderate pore sizes endow the frameworks with size-exclusion effect.

elements.content: To prove our hypothesis about the adsorption ability of NKU-103, the adsorption experiments were carried out toward some dyes of different sizes and charges, including Coumarin (CM), Sudan I (SD I), Rhodamine 6G (R6G), Methyl Orange (MO), Methylene Blue trihydrate (MB), Leucocrystal Violet (LV), Rhodamine B (RB) and Victoria Blue (VB) (). As a comparion, the adsorption performance of NKU-102 was also measured.
elements.clean_text: To prove our hypothesis about the adsorption ability of NKU-103, the adsorption experiments were carried out toward some dyes of different sizes and charges, including Coumarin (CM), Sudan I (SD I), Rhodamine 6G (R6G), Methyl Orange (MO), Methylene Blue trihydrate (MB), Leucocrystal Violet (LV), Rhodamine B (RB) and Victoria Blue (VB) (). As a comparion, the adsorption performance of NKU-102 was also measured.

<title>Structures of Eight Dyes Used as Adsorbates
in This Paper</title>

elements.clean_text: 1  Structures of Eight Dyes Used as Adsorbates in This Paper

elements.content: Typical adsorption experiment was carried out by immersing freshly prepared samples of NKU-102 or NKU-103 in the ethanol solution containing an organic dye. By the naked eye, it is easily identified that smaller cationic MB is adsorbed much more effectively by NKU-103, as indicated by the fading of MB solution as well as the coloring of the originally colorless crystals. Whereas no obvious change was observed in the system containing neutral dyes (i.e., CM, SD I, R6G), anionic dyes (i.e., CM, SD I, R6G, MO), and large cationic dyes (i.e., LV, RB, and VB) (Figure S10 and c). Meanwhile, the MB adsorption was also monitored by UV/vis spectroscopy, in which the absorbance of MB decreases significantly upon the addition of NKU-103 (a), but remains almost unchanged upon the addition of NKU-102 (Figure S10). Different adsorption performance of NKU-102 and NKU-103 can be interpreted reasonably by their different structures. NKU-102 is of 3D sealed framework with channels blocked by the coordinating BTC3-ligands, which denies the effective diffusion of dyes into the framework. In constrast, NKU-103 possesses open triangular helical channels with a dynamic dimension of approximately 9 Å, which endows NKU-103 the capability of guest adsorption.
elements.clean_text: Typical adsorption experiment was carried out by immersing freshly prepared samples of NKU-102 or NKU-103 in the ethanol solution containing an organic dye. By the naked eye, it is easily identified that smaller cationic MB is adsorbed much more effectively by NKU-103, as indicated by the fading of MB solution as well as the coloring of the originally colorless crystals. Whereas no obvious change was observed in the system containing neutral dyes (i.e., CM, SD I, R6G), anionic dyes (i.e., CM, SD I, R6G, MO), and large cationic dyes (i.e., LV, RB, and VB) (Figure S10 and c). Meanwhile, the MB adsorption was also monitored by UV/vis spectroscopy, in which the absorbance of MB decreases significantly upon the addition of NKU-103 (a), but remains almost unchanged upon the addition of NKU-102 (Figure S10). Different adsorption performance of NKU-102 and NKU-103 can be interpreted reasonably by their different structures. NKU-102 is of 3D sealed framework with channels blocked by the coordinating BTC3-ligands, which denies the effective diffusion of dyes into the framework. In constrast, NKU-103 possesses open triangular helical channels with a dynamic dimension of approximately 9 Å, which endows NKU-103 the capability of guest adsorption.

elements.content: (a) UV/vis spectra of MB solutions upon adsorption by NKU-103; (b) structure of MB dye optimized by DFT calculation; (c) photographs of MB solutions before and after 24 h adsorption with NKU-103.
elements.clean_text: 4  (a) UV/vis spectra of MB solutions upon adsorption by NKU-103; (b) structure of MB dye optimized by DFT calculation; (c) photographs of MB solutions before and after 24 h adsorption with NKU-103.

elements.content: Meanwhile, the observed selective adsorption of NKU-103 toward MB may also be easily and reliably explained in terms of crystal structure analysis. That is, the cooperation of electrostatic interactin between anionic framework and cationic molecules, as well as accessible channel accounts for the selective adsorption of NKU-103 toward cationic dyes of matched size such as MB (Figure S11).
elements.clean_text: Meanwhile, the observed selective adsorption of NKU-103 toward MB may also be easily and reliably explained in terms of crystal structure analysis. That is, the cooperation of electrostatic interactin between anionic framework and cationic molecules, as well as accessible channel accounts for the selective adsorption of NKU-103 toward cationic dyes of matched size such as MB (Figure S11).

elements.content: To support our hypothesis, the adsorption behaviors of NKU-103 was further explored toward other cationic dyes of similar theoretical sizes predicted by density functional theoretical simulation, e.g., Pyronin Y (PY) and Thiazole Orange (TO) (Figures S12 and S13). The UV–vis absorption spectra show that both these two dye molecules were effectively adsorbed by NKU-103 (Figure S14).
elements.clean_text: To support our hypothesis, the adsorption behaviors of NKU-103 was further explored toward other cationic dyes of similar theoretical sizes predicted by density functional theoretical simulation, e.g., Pyronin Y (PY) and Thiazole Orange (TO) (Figures S12 and S13). The UV-vis absorption spectra show that both these two dye molecules were effectively adsorbed by NKU-103 (Figure S14).

elements.content: The selective adsorption of NKU-103 toward MB, PY, and TO was also testified in the presence of others dyes by UV–vis spectral meausrement. As shown in Figures S15, S16, and S17, after 24 h adsorption, the UV–vis absorption peaks of target small cationic dyes, 655 nm of MB, 540 nm of PY, and 495 nm of TO, are all eliminated completely, whereas that of other dyes remain unchanged. This further testified to the selective adsorption of NKU-103 toward small cation dyes including (MB (4.97 Å), PY (4.97 Å), and TO (7.16 Å)) even in the presence of big cation dyes such as (LV (13.29 Å), RB (8.20 Å), and VB (12.80)).
elements.clean_text: The selective adsorption of NKU-103 toward MB, PY, and TO was also testified in the presence of others dyes by UV-vis spectral meausrement. As shown in Figures S15, S16, and S17, after 24 h adsorption, the UV-vis absorption peaks of target small cationic dyes, 655 nm of MB, 540 nm of PY, and 495 nm of TO, are all eliminated completely, whereas that of other dyes remain unchanged. This further testified to the selective adsorption of NKU-103 toward small cation dyes including (MB (4.97 Å), PY (4.97 Å), and TO (7.16 Å)) even in the presence of big cation dyes such as (LV (13.29 Å), RB (8.20 Å), and VB (12.80)).

elements.content: It is worth noting that adsorbed MB molecules located not only on the surface of but also inside the NKU-103 crystal, which is testified by the uniform coloring within the whole crystal observed for the broken crystal under optical microscopy (Figure S18 and Figure S19). Furthermore, in order to give a better visualization of the adsorption uniformity inside NKU-103, confocal laser scanning microscopy (CLSM) was utilized to characterize MB@NKU-103, PY@NKU-103, and TO@NKU-103 crystals, and the observed well-distributed fluorescent emission of organic dyes through the whole crystal indicates the effective diffusion of organic dyes inside the whole crystal (Figures S20–S23). The diffusion of dye molecules into NKU-103 may be realized through ions and guest exchange that commonly reported in several publications in the literature. The solvent molecules inside the framework of as-prepared NKU-103 are capable of escaping from the framework as testified by the thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) shown in Figures S6 and S7.
elements.clean_text: It is worth noting that adsorbed MB molecules located not only on the surface of but also inside the NKU-103 crystal, which is testified by the uniform coloring within the whole crystal observed for the broken crystal under optical microscopy (Figure S18 and Figure S19). Furthermore, in order to give a better visualization of the adsorption uniformity inside NKU-103, confocal laser scanning microscopy (CLSM) was utilized to characterize MB@NKU-103, PY@NKU-103, and TO@NKU-103 crystals, and the observed well-distributed fluorescent emission of organic dyes through the whole crystal indicates the effective diffusion of organic dyes inside the whole crystal (Figures S20-S23). The diffusion of dye molecules into NKU-103 may be realized through ions and guest exchange that commonly reported in several publications in the literature. The solvent molecules inside the framework of as-prepared NKU-103 are capable of escaping from the framework as testified by the thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) shown in Figures S6 and S7.

elements.content: In conclusion, the unique coordination behaviors of H2PyC ligand toward Zn­(II) ion was investigated in the presence of H3BTC ligand. Different reaction temperature was found to trigger different assembly processes. As result the obtained two anionic MOFs, NKU-102 and NKU-103, differing from each other in the coordination environment and framework, exhibit distinct adsorption behaviors toward organic dyes.
elements.clean_text: In conclusion, the unique coordination behaviors of H2PyC ligand toward Zn(II) ion was investigated in the presence of H3BTC ligand. Different reaction temperature was found to trigger different assembly processes. As result the obtained two anionic MOFs, NKU-102 and NKU-103, differing from each other in the coordination environment and framework, exhibit distinct adsorption behaviors toward organic dyes.

cln_elements.content: Classical coordination modes of carboxylate (a) and parazole (c). Electrostatic potential map of H2BDC (b) and H2PyC (d). The structures were optimized at the level of B3LYP/6-311g (d) by Gaussian 09 package (Supporting Information).
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  Classical coordination modes of carboxylate (a) and parazole (c). Electrostatic potential map of H2BDC (b) and H2PyC (d). The structures were optimized at the level of B3LYP/6-311g (d) by Gaussian 09 package (Supporting Information).

cln_elements.content: Crystal structure of NKU-102. (a) Coordination environment of Zinc ion; (b) 1D hexagonal channels constructed by PyC2– and zinc ions; (c) octahedral cage Zn12(BTC)2(PyC)6; (d) simplified octahedral cage; (e) packing of octahedral cages.
cln_elements.clean_text: 2  Crystal structure of NKU-102. (a) Coordination environment of Zinc ion; (b) 1D hexagonal channels constructed by PyC2- and zinc ions; (c) octahedral cage Zn12(BTC)2(PyC)6; (d) simplified octahedral cage; (e) packing of octahedral cages.

cln_elements.content: Crystal structure of NKU-103. (a) Coordination environment of zinc ion; (b) framework built from BTC3– ligands and Zn (II); (c) right-handed double-helix; (d) left-handed single helix; (e) 3D framework with open triangular helical channel; (f) tiling representation of the open 1D chiral helical channels; (g) 1D chiral helical channels.
cln_elements.clean_text: 3  Crystal structure of NKU-103. (a) Coordination environment of zinc ion; (b) framework built from BTC3- ligands and Zn (II); (c) right-handed double-helix; (d) left-handed single helix; (e) 3D framework with open triangular helical channel; (f) tiling representation of the open 1D chiral helical channels; (g) 1D chiral helical channels.

metadata.title:

Frameworks with Distinct Performance in Organic Dye Adsorption
